												Claire is a 2D Sidescrolling Psychological Horror game that, as of right now, ended up being too monotonous for me to want to finish. Centered around the titular Claire and her troubled family life, the story, while not exactly outstanding, was still interesting enough for me to try to press onward, and the atmosphere is fittingly moody and subdued for the most part (this does not apply to the very beginning of the game).The gameplay, on the other hand, is painfully tedious. It involves exploring rather large areas with little direction, mostly by walking because sprinting can be done for only a few seconds at a time. There are many empty rooms in these areas, and while I'll admit it's unrealistic to expect every room to have a function, it's also a chore to go through them all to make sure nothing is missed. Objects like posters and televisions decorate the background every now and then, but for the most part these areas are just dreary hallway after dreary hallway. It doesn't help that there are sidequests in the game that generally require finding items and taking them back to their rightful owners; after I got one to find three at once I just stopped caring.Enemies that I can only describe as silly-looking scribbles appear in set locations; these enemies cannot be fought, only fled from. They can knock down doors and give chase, which I like as an idea; however, because they are fast and can do this repeatedly, I ended up getting more irritated at losing track of my location than unnerved. Oftentimes I would escape only to end up discovering the way to proceed was back past that enemy. Hiding places exist, but they are sparse and generally not helpful. Later on, there are also human-like enemies that don't attack but instead make Claire frightened with their presence, and if she gets scared enough she starts to lose health over time. They soon start to show up in groups, sometimes one room after another, and the only way to lower Claire's fear is to either use one of the rarer restorative items or wait it out in an empty room. To say the least, the enemy interactions in this game tend to be agreeable concepts spoiled by a complete lack of counterplay, exacerbating the frustrations of exploration.I feel as if the game is marred by a lack of technical polish as well. Even with all the graphical options turned off the game never ran at a smooth, consistent FPS, and several of the menus did not respond well to controller input. Text would sometimes advance by itself without the chance for me to read it, and several lines have typos which ruin the immersion. The game does not state what an item is when trying to pick it up with a full inventory. There's no prompt when using restoratives, which caused me to accidentally use them when I had no reason to do so. There are two sources of light Claire carries, a lighter and a flashlight, but there never seems to be a reason to use the latter because the game is never that dark and it uses up batteries (which admittedly aren't used for anything else). Save points did not reliably respond to my inputs to open them. Lastly, jumping is possible, but for some reason the camera remains vertically centered on Claire as she hops, even though none of the rooms I encountered are taller than the screen nor did any of them require any height-scaling; this honestly made me nauseous.The most damning thing about Claire, however, is that it's never as scary as it wants to be. The enemies are uninspired, the few moments apparently intended to terrorize fall flat, and the fact that Claire's dog alerts her of potential dangers while simultaneously being immune to them himself takes a lot of potential dread out of her situation. Along with that, while Claire verbalizes her anxiety, her expression never changes to match it; quite frankly, I can't remember a single time when she didn't have the same dour expression on her face. Save for the scant story-related scenes I encountered, the game is, overall, incredibly dull.I managed to reach the beginning of what I assume is the third and final part of the game before deciding to give up. It's a shame, because the scene right beforehand was riveting and implied a conclusive explanation to the game's events, but the two-and-a-half hours I spent with Claire felt more like five with the content of one. Don't bother.p.s. there was an achievement called "But Who Was Phone?" and it made me want to mutilate myself

												I'm 50/50 on this one.This game runs in the same vein as Lone Survivor, which I enjoyed up until the very end since I simply could not beat the final monster (GRRR). This and Lone Survivor also pay homage to Silent Hill down to the sound effects for picking up and using items (which I honestly can't get enough of). The main character Claire even somewhat looks like Heather from SH 3.It's easy to get lost, which makes it both a bit frustrating and compelling because there's nothing more fun than opening doors over and over again and exploring, which is also very typical of Silent Hill.What detracted from the experience was that the big reveal didn't really hit me. I really didn't get what the game was trying to convey in regards to the traumatic past that Claire was trying to forget. It was almost as if it were ticking boxes of typical ♥♥♥♥♥♥, dysfunctional childhood tropes but they didn't seem in-sync nor were they pulled off as coherently as they should have. I still don't really know what happened other than  Mom in hospital. Catatonic schizophrenia maybe? Ethan...I have no idea, her brother was drowned by her mother? Her father...left/died, I don't know. Claire killed herself. Yeah, I guess it could have been compelling if it had been told a bit more clearly, but the attempt to parse out information and keep the mystery going feel flat with me.I'd still give this a try if you liked Lone Survivor or Silent Hill 1-3, but I won't promise you'll feel very emotionally fulfilled with the awkward story-telling.
